Dear Mr. Gonzalez:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
January 17, 2023. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular license will be issued. If you
fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any questions.
In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone immediately, please
contact the area manager at (616)204-6992.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the
follo wing:
CCI Rule 400.4147 Dental Care
(1) A dental examination within 12 months prior
to admission shall be documented or there
shall be an examination not later than 90
calendar days following admission.
Three of three open youth files reviewed lacked a completed dental exam
within 90 days from admission. One youth's exam was reported to be
completed 16 days late and was not dated. Two youth's files did not contain a
c ompleted dental.
CCI Rule 400.4144 Admission health screening; physical
examinations.
(2) An institution shall have the following
documentation of an admission physical
examination for each resident, unless an
earlier examination is medically indicated.
(b) For a resident 3 years of age or older, a
physical examination shall have been
completed within 1 year prior to admission or
a new physical examination shall be
completed within 30 calendar days after
admission.
Two of three open youth files reviewed lacked a completed physical exam
within 30 days of admission. One youth's physical exam was completed 4 days
late and another youth lacked documentation of a physical exam being
c ompleted.
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions (not detention or shelter care
institutions); Initial treatment plan.
(2) The initial treatment plan developed by the
social worker shall document input from the
resident, the resident’s parents, direct care
staff, and the referral source, unless
documented as inappropriate.
Three of three open youth files reviewed lacked a signature by youth 14+ on
t heir initial treatment plans.

CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee Records
(2) An institution shall maintain employee
records for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following
information prior to employment or at the time
specified in this rule.
(k) Verification of health where specified by
institution policy.
Two of three new employee files lacked documentation of TB results prior to
hire. These results were later found elsewhere on site at the facility; however,
the results were not part of the employee's file.
CCI Rule 400.4128 Initial staff orientation and ongoing staff training.
(3) The licensee shall document that each staff
person whose function is covered by these
rules has participated in a minimum of 50
clock hours of planned training within the first
year of employment and a minimum of 25
clock hours of training annually thereafter
related to the employee’s job function. At least
16 of the 50 hours provided in the first year
shall be orientation provided prior to the
assumption of duties.
Three of three new employee files lacked documentation of 16 hours of
orientation being completed as required prior to assumption of duties.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• The agency has multiple case records containing youth information. It is
recommended that youth have one uniform file per the licensing rule.
3

• The agency has multiple records containing employee information (i.e. one file in
Human Resources and one file and/or other documents on-site at the facility). It is
recommended that employees have one complete file per the licensing rule.
• It is recommended the agency follow a consistent process for new employees to
ensure all licensing requirements are met prior to hire and prior to assumption of
duties.
• All requested items need to be accessible and on-site on the day of the audit.
• One staff file reviewed for an employee over 12 months had an annual evaluation
not in this period of review. The annual review was dated 1/1/21-12/31/21 but was
not dated by the supervisor until 2/9/22 and was not dated by the employee until
3/12/22. The facility must complete, sign and date annual evaluations by January
31st as required.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• The agency was notified as part of the quarterly unannounced visit they needed
to complete their next fire drill during 3rd shift.
• The agency was notified as part of the quarterly unannounced visit the spare fire
extinguisher in the staff office was last inspected in January 2022 and needed to
be updated this month. In addition, the agency was notified the fire extinguisher
must remain stored at least 4 inches off the ground.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency submitted one acceptable corrective action plan not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period. The CAP was in response to two violations
received during their 2022 Interim Inspection. They have implemented the CAP and
no further issues have been identified when transferring a youth from one Bethany
program to another such as health screening and grievience procedures.
Chief Administrator (CA) Assessment:
CA noted there have been no barriers or systemic factors that have impacted rule
compliance. CA noted COVID positive staff challenge the agency’s ability to stay in
ratio, but the case manager and therapist continue to help by covering shifts as
needed. CA reported during the last inspection, there were two rules they were found
in violation for related to missing documents due to youth transferring between
Bethany programs, and they have resolved both violations successfully. CA noted
they had an increase in AWOL episodes for youth and are continuing to explore ways
to increase engagement in program participation. CA reported they continue to
struggle to fill youth specialist positions, but they are continuing efforts by partnering
with Human Resources, posting openings on social media and peer recruitment. CA
reported they are working with USCCB and ORR to secure additional referrals and
provide services to additional youth since the agency’s capacity has increased to 12
youth. CA noted the agency will have bi-weekly team meetings to review applicable
4

policies and procedures as well as share program progress to allow for adjustments
to programming as needed.
Staff and Youth Interviews:
Youth and staff interviews were very positive. The youth did not have any concerns or
complaints to report. They feel very supported and safe at Bellaview. They feel staff
meet their needs and are very kind. Staff reported they feel Bellaview, as well as
Bethany Christian Services, are very supportive agencies. They feel they can go to
upper management to express concerns and feel their concerns are heard and acted
upon. One concern noted was a continued lack of communication, which was also
noted during the quarterly unannounced visit in October 2022. Staff noted there are a
lack of defined roles amongst staff. Staff are feeling overwhelmed without having
established and defined roles or knowing who to report to for certain issues. For
example, staff reported Youth Specialist meetings used to occur bi-weekly and those
are no longer occurring. As a result, there have been communication gaps between
staff. Staff feel implementing the biweekly youth specialist meetings could improve
the communication between staff, which will in turn positively effect staff interactions
and consistency with youth. However, it is unknown who should be initiating and
organizing those meetings as well as who should hold staff accountable to attend.
Financial Overview:
There are no financial concerns identified based on a review of the facility’s budget
and the agency’s financial audit.
PREA Compliance (if applicable):
Not Applicable
Description of Agency Walkthrough:
An on-site inspection and walkthrough of the facility occurred on January 17, 2023.
There were no issues or safety concerns noted.
5

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the facility will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
January 25, 2023
